correction_response:
This tweet is misleading. While it's true that the deficit is projected to shrink to $1.0 trillion in 2022, this is not due to actions taken by the current administration. In fact, the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates that at least $2.5 trillion has been added to deficits through 2031 due to the American Rescue Plan, the bipartisan infrastructure law, and various executive orders. Furthermore, the CBO's projection of the deficit for 2022 is now $118 billion less than it was in July 2021, but its projection of the cumulative deficit over the 2022–2031 period is $2.4 trillion more. 
https://www.factcheck.org/2022/04/bidens-deficit-spin/
https://www.cbo.gov/publication/58147
note_1_text: While that number is factually correct, it’s lacking some context.  Most of the drop is because of the recovery from COVID, and the government spending during that time coming to an end.  There’s no indication that any policies have specifically targeted the deficit.    https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/biden-administration-forecasts-1-03-trillion-deficit-down-by-nearly-400-billion    https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2022/jul/28/janet-yellen/white-houses-big-deficit-cut-and-why-it-merits-ast/
note_2_text: There is no solid proof that the deficit has been reduced by $1 trillion dollars. The U.S. National Debt is close to a record $31 trillion. Federal spending is over $6 trillion    https://www.usdebtclock.org/

- CBO projects that the federal budget deficit will shrink to $1.0 trillion in 2022 (it was $2.8 trillion last year) and that the annual shortfall would average $1.6 trillion from 2023 to 2032. Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/58147 published on 2022-05-05 00:00:00

- CBO projects that if current laws governing taxes and spending generally remained unchanged, federal debt held by the public would first exceed 100 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2021 and would reach 107 percent of GDP, its highest level in the nation’s history, by 2023. Debt would continue to increase in most years thereafter, reaching 195 percent of GDP by 2050. Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/56783 published on 2020-12-05 00:00:00

- “It’s pretty silly,” Marc Goldwein , senior vice president and senior policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, said of Biden’s deficit-cutting claims. “He [Biden] didn’t cut the deficit, he increased it.” Reference: https://www.factcheck.org/2022/04/bidens-deficit-spin/ published on 2022-04-27 22:20:04

- CBO’s projection of the deficit for 2022 is now $118 billion less than it was in July 2021, but its projection of the cumulative deficit over the 2022–2031 period is $2.4 trillion more (see Appendix A ). Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/58147 published on 2022-05-05 00:00:00

- The president proposed cutting the top corporate rate to 28 percent from 35 percent, addressing a long-standing gripe by U.S. corporations that the rate is too high. - Making the task of deficit reduction more complicated is the economy’s slow recovery from the severe recession. By CBO’s estimate, the economy is now about 5 million jobs short of where it would be if the unemployment rate was down to its sustainable level and participation in the labor force was back up to its trend. The shortage of jobs has occurred mostly because demand for goods and services has been weak relative to the productive capacity of the economy. That shortfall in demand has stemmed largely from the lingering effects of the housing bubble and financial crisis. Also contributing, however, has been the most abrupt fiscal tightening that has occurred since the end of World War II, as the federal deficit shrank from about 10 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in fiscal year 2009 to about 4 percent in 2013. - The Reagan tax cut was huge. The top rate fell from 70 percent to 50 percent. The tax cut didn’t pay for itself. - The most appropriate test of the revenue impact of the TCJA is to compare actual revenues in FY2018 with predicted revenues in FY2018 assuming Congress had not passed the legislation. In fact, the actual amount of revenue collected in FY2018 was significantly lower than the Congressional Budget Office’s (CBO) projection of FY2018 revenue made in January 2017—before the tax cuts were signed into law in December 2017. The shortfall was $275 billion, or 7.6% of revenues that were expected before the tax cuts took place. Given that the economy grew, and in the absence of another policy that could have caused a large revenue loss, the data imply that the TCJA substantially reduced revenues (Figure 1).
